application.name: Unit Calculator
application.description: Effortlessly convert between units with our online tool. Make accurate conversions for any calculation you need.

tool.name: {game_name} {units.first_unit_name} Calculator
tool.description: Easily convert between {game_name} units, including {units.first_unit_name} and {units.second_unit_name}, with our online tool. Get accurate conversions in seconds!
tool.introduction: For players who want to simplify {units.first_unit_name} calculations, the {tool_name} is a useful tool. With the ability to convert between different unit types and explanations on the math involved, {tool_name} just got easier. Upgrade your experience with the {tool_name} today.

examples.title: How many {units.first_unit_name} are <script>document.write({units.first_unit_size} * 10 + 1)</script> {units.second_unit_name}?
examples.text: To determine the solution to this question, divide <script>document.write({units.first_unit_size} * 10 + 1)</script> by {units.first_unit_size}. The quotient is 10 and the remainder is 1. Therefore, the answer to the question is 10 {units.first_unit_name} and 1 {units.second_unit_name}.

examples.title: What is the conversion of <script>document.write({units.first_unit_size} * 56)</script> {units.second_unit_name} to {units.first_unit_name}?
examples.text: You can calculate the anwer of this question by dividing <script>document.write({units.first_unit_size} * 56)</script> with {units.first_unit_size}. This will result in 56. So the answer to the questions is 56 {units.first_unit_name}.

examples.title: What is the equivalent quantity of {units.first_unit_name} for <script>document.write({units.first_unit_size} * 64)</script> {units.second_unit_name} in {game_name}?
examples.text: You can calculate the anwer to this question by dividing <script>document.write({units.first_unit_size} * 64)</script> with {units.first_unit_size}. This will result in 64 {units.first_unit_name}.

examples.title: How many {units.second_unit_name} fit in a single {units.first_unit_name}?

questions.title: How to calculate the number of {units.first_unit_name} in {game_name}?
questions.text: You can calculate the number of {units.first_unit_name} by dividing the number of {units.second_unit_name} you have by 64 and then rounding your answer down to the nearest whole number. The number that you just calculated is how many {units.first_unit_name} you have! You can then calculate the number of {units.second_unit_name} remaining by subtracting the number of {units.first_unit_name} multiplied by 64 from the total number of {units.second_unit_name}. If you follow these steps, you can easily calculate how many {units.first_unit_name} a given number of {units.second_unit_name} is.

questions.title: How to use the {tool_name}?
questions.text: This calculator is designed to convert between  {units.second_unit_name} to {units.first_unit_name}, as well as other unit combinations. Begin by choosing the unit that corresponds to your current quantity, then select your desired unit. Next, input the amount you have, and the calculator will convert it to the corresponding amount in your desired unit.

questions.title: Why is this {tool_name} useful?
questions.text: {game_name} has its own units in the game. It can often be hard to wrap your head around all the different units, it's therefore useful to have a simple calculator which calculates between these units. Our Resource Calculator for example requires you to fill in an integer instead of '12 {units.first_unit_name} and 2 {units.second_unit_name}'. By using this tool, you can quickly convert these {units.first_unit_name} into integers.

questions.title: Why can't you just divide {units.second_unit_name} by {units.first_unit_size} in a regular calculator?
questions.text: If you would just divide a number by 64 you would often end up with a decimal number. This will give you an idea of the amount of {units.first_unit_name}, but nothing about the amount of {units.second_unit_name} left over. In a regular calculator it will cost you 2 steps to convert a number to {units.first_unit_name}, but a {tool_name} will calculate this all at once, which makes converting large amounts of different units less painful.
